audio_caption: The clip starts with one male speaker introducing the song "Stitches" by Shawn Mendes. He then passes the speaking role to another male speaker, who says they will "start with the song structure". The first male speaker then returns, outlining the song structure as "verse, pre-chorus, chorus", followed by another repetition of that section, then a bridge, a chorus, and an outro. He notes this structure is basic and common in modern songs, being the most popular song structure today.

The audio clip starts with an explanation of how to break a song into guitar parts: verse, pre-chorus, chorus, and bridge. A male speaker continues by saying, "we're using the same four chords for the entire song just in different orders", then invites the listener to check out a link for lyrics and chords. He gives a directive to tune up and put a capo on the first fret. The man says he'd appreciate "a thumbs up or a comment" as motivation for "making more videos".

The audio begins with a male speaker encouraging listeners to subscribe to access his latest content. This spoken segment transitions to a strummed acoustic guitar, playing a simple, repetitive chord progression, suggesting an upbeat mood.

The clip begins with the distinct sound of a stringed instrument, most likely a guitar, playing chords. A male voice then enters, introducing the chords being played as A minor, G, C, and F. The male speaker then guides the listener through playing the verse of a song, clarifying "this isn't too complicated," involving playing "on the one and the and on beat one" and "beats two to four...just playing on the and", playing each chord for one bar. The male narrator provides counting examples like "one and two", explaining the rhythmic pattern, before re-demonstrating the song progression with guitar. The male narrator concludes, stating, "that's all there is to it", and the sound of the guitar playing the song progression repeats.

The audio begins with a male speaker introducing a "pre-chorus". He then states the chord progression, which consists of "F," "G," "A minor," and "G," followed by a brief pause. The sound of an acoustic guitar playing each of these chords can be heard as the speaker announces them.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining a guitar part, specifying a rhythm pattern involving playing "on the one and the two" followed by "three and four and" with chord changes. He then demonstrates the described guitar playing.  Next, he concludes with the statement "that's all there is to it." Then, more of the guitar playing is heard,  shifting into a music excerpt of a singer playing acoustic guitar with a somber tone.

The clip begins with a single speaker, male, who transitions into discussing music. The speaker identifies the sections of a song, mentioning chords such as "A minor", "G", "C", and "F", and describes the rhythm as playing "on the one, two and the end of three, then four and". He demonstrates the chord progression in sequence. The clip concludes with music being played, presumably on a guitar, that exhibits a light and rhythmic folk style.

The clip begins with a male speaker introducing the bridge of a song. He mentions the chord progression and explains a palm-muting technique. He describes what palm-muting is, where on the guitar to place the palm, and its effect on the sound. He demonstrates this technique, playing the chords one by one, advising that it may take some practice. The speaker then states that if one can play the four parts, one can play the entire song and asks if the listener enjoyed the video. There is brief acoustic guitar music at the start and interspersed with his speech.

A male speaker starts by giving a command, suggesting the listener subscribe to a channel for immediate access to content updates. After suggesting the subscription, the speaker directs the listener to click on either of two video options to begin their "next guitar adventure".
